bibl.title: Letter from Robert Carter to William Robertson, January 9, 1728

div1.p: Robert Carter writes to his old friend William Robertson, January 9, 1728, clerk of the Council, requesting him to use his influence to help Carter choose the sheriff in the northern area of the Northern Neck, and to have him urge the clerks of three counties to pay the fees due for ordinary and marriage licenses.

div1.head: Letter from Robert Carter to William Robertson, January 9, 1728

opener.dateline:
[Corotoman, Lancaster County, Virginia]
January the 9th: 1727/8
Mr. William Robertson

div1.p:
It hath bin no Small pleasure frequently to me to have hear
of your deliverance so well from your late most Calamnitous
Disaster and that your wooden Legg is now become so familiar to
you that you are Qualifyed for all the parts of your business

I am now under a Strong fitt of the Gout and have bin so
for these Ten days which takes from me all hopes of giving my
Attendance at the first of the Assembly a very threatening Season
for a broken Constitution to be abroad in, You know Colonel Drysdale
always favourd me and I may Say Colonel Spotswood before him
in the Nomination of our northern Sherif which is some kindness
to me in geting in my Qt. rents and I would flatter my Self
to meet with the Same Indulgence under the present regment It may
lye in your way to Drop in a Seasonable word upon this Occasion
and if it does I dare say you will not slip the Opportunity In de=
feating any Attempt may be made from Some other Qr.—

Some Clerks that lye in your way to call upon have not yet paid
me their Ordinary and Marriage Lycences to wit Isle of wight
Northampton, and Surry, if you will give your Self the trouble of
managing these Gentlemen you will oblige my Lord Orkny
as well as my Self, I have already writ to Mr. Hickman but had no
answer from him I wish you a Compleat recovery and am
div1.closer:
Sir—
Yor. Affectionat most humble Servt.

div1.head: NOTES
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Robert Carter Letter Book, 1727 April 13-1728 July 23, Carter Family Papers, Virginia Historical Society, Richmond.
The name of Carter's home, "Corotoman," the county, and colony have been added for clarity to this unheaded draft.
[1] Alexander Spotswood (1646-1740) had been the governor from 1710 to 1722.

[2] Quit rent was the term used for the payment due from the holder of land to the "lord of the manor," in this case, to the proprietors of the Northern Neck. Carter as the proprietor's agent, collected these payments. No services were required of the landholder as had been true in mediaeval times.
[3] Carter uses "regiment" to mean the government or administration, a meaning obsolete today.

[4] Richard Hickman (d. 1732) had been deputy clerk of Middlesex County in 1709. After Governor Hugh Drysdale's death, the Council appointed him to manage the Governor's house and its gardens. His name appears a number of times in the Council minutes as he was the doorkeeper, and as he took out land patents. From Carter's letter to William Robertson 1727 July 15, in which he complains that "Mr. Hickman is very dilatory with his probatted Administrations," it seems that Hickman must have done other work for the colonial government. (Edward W. James. "Libraries in Colonial Virginia." William and Mary Quarterly. 3[1,#4, Apr. 1895]:248-51 for Hickman's inventory recorded 1732 May 15 listing many books; "Notes from the Journal of the House of Burgesses, 1712-1726." William and Mary Quarterly. 21[1,#4, April 1913]:257 mentions his being Council doorkeeper; "Notes from the Journal of the House of Burgesses, 1727-1734, William and Mary Quarterly.22[1, #1, July 1913]:54,56-58, mentions his being clerk of the Committee of Propositions and Grievances; and McIlwaine. Executive Journals of the Council. . . ., 4[1721-1739]:114. )
